subject: Re: [junit] Re: Problems with assertEquals()
msgSnippet: On Wed, 02 Mar 2005 23:02:46 -0600, J. B. Rainsberger ... Oh, I m not offended or anything of the sort.  I m just chuckling that you and I specifically have
messageBody:
On Wed, 02 Mar 2005 23:02:46 -0600, J. B. Rainsberger
<jbrains@...> wrote:
>
> Kevin Klinemeier wrote:
> > Heh, to quote Yogi Berra, "It's like Deja Vu all over again"
>
> It's OK, Kevin; you can just summarize. I know the issues, and I'm not
> trying to force you to type too much.

Oh, I'm not offended or anything of the sort. I'm just chuckling that
you and I specifically have discussed this issue before. I'm a quick
typist, and I ought to be: I have all this practice from documenting
my test methods and assert statements! :)

>
> > Just like the test name often needs further clarification (never pass
> > up an oportunity for documentation), often the reason for the
> > assertion is not self-apparent. You can try to argue that "it ought
> > to be, or rewrite your code!" but, as before, I think you're straying
> > too close to the "Java code is self-documenting" argument, which I
> > find ... dubious at best.
>
> I don't know. I just wrote this in an XHTMLUnit test today:
>
> assertXpathExists(
> somewhereThereIsA(formNamed("demographics"))
> .eventuallyContainingA(textFieldNamed("firstName")), document);
>
> This translated to the XPath expression
>
> //form[@name="demographics"]//input[@type="text" and @name="firstName"]
>
> Is a comment or a failure message going to make that clearer?

I haven't had a need for XHTMLUnit, I'm mostly commenting about
vanilla JUnit usage. That said, what message does the above generate
in your error report?

>> Or to put it pithily:
> >
> > I feel that I'm proficient with Java, but when I want to explain
> > something, especially *why* something, I generally prefer English.
>
> I agree and explain "why" in English, but nost of the time, test case
> class name, method name and line number is enough for me to know what
> failed, from which I generally can determine why it failed. If not, then
> my tests are too big (and that's an entirely different problem).

Do you have the same experience with tests you're not the author of?
This is where I've found it especially helpful, or frustrating if it
doesn't exist. Of course *my* logic and reasoning is always obvious,
it's those other punks that write stuff I can't understand.
(sarcasm!)

These additional comments have also been helpful if I'm debugging a
section I neither wrote, nor studied the original requirements. An
example of that situation is code written for features implemented
before I joined the proeject.

-Kevin
